NOTE:
Man Qiu (1919-1992), originally named Shuai Shiyi, was born at Qingshen, Sichuan province. Graduating from Yanan Military and Political University, he devoted himself to military design and construction management. Apart from being an expert and leader in the Chinese techonology industry, he was also an enthusiast of the liberal arts with particular connoisseurship in photography, calligraphy and ink painting.

lots.consigner_information: LOTS 1376 PROPERTY OF AN AMERICAN GENTLEMAN After he returned to China from Europe in the 1920s, Lin Fengmian was appointed the president of the Hangzhou National College of Art, pioneering the integration of Western modernism with Chinese traditional painting. In the 1950s, Lin became enthralled with Chinese traditional opera, from Beijing Opera to Kun Opera, resulting in numerous inspirations for his artworks. Opera Figures depicts a famous scene from the Beijing opera, the Banquet at Hongmen. The figure in blue robes and opera mask is Zhang Liang, the trusted aide of future Han emperor, Liu Bang. Lin Fengmian uses only two strokes to represent the eyebrows and nose, as well as a striking slab of colour to depict a figure of shrewdness and valor. The white-faced figure to his right with the shou -character eyebrows is Xiang Yu, the warlord who was eventually defeated by Liu Bang. Lin Fengmian uses a single colour to paint his facial makeup, where the heavy strokes and exaggerated lines emphasise the warlords brutal and reckless disposition. As the two figures confront each other against the soldiers in the background, the Banquet at Hongmen reveals itself to be a perilous affair. Here, Cubist and Expressionist techniques are in perfect fusion with the Chinese traditions: the palette is simple and bright; the composition lively and rhythmic.

lots.consigner_information: LOTS 2759-2788 IMPORTANT CHINESE PAINTINGS - FORMERLY THE PROPERTY OF THE DR. K. S. LO COLLECTION Dr. K. S. Lo was born on 2 February 1910 in Guangdong, China. At age 10 he went to Malaysia with his mother and at age 20 he went to Hong Kong. In 1935 he graduated from the University of Hong Kong with a BA degree in commerce and business. After graduation he joined the company where his father worked and was soon appointed Hong Kong manager of the firm's real estate branch. Dr. K.S. Lo began his Vitasoy business in the winter of 1937, when he was 27 years old in Shanghai, after attending a talk on "Soya Bean: The Cow of China". His Vitasoy business grew to become one of the most recognized brands in Hong Kong and in many other global regions. Dr K.S. Lo had a great passion for Chinese art and culture, and he donated 605 yixing teapots and other tea ware pieces in 1995, enabling the creation of the K.S. Lo gallery at the Museum of Tea Ware, at Flagstaff House inside the Hong Kong Park (fig.1). Furthermore, Dr. Lo also donated many important ceramics from well-known major kilns from as early as the Western Zhou period to the 20th century. These paintings represent but a small part of his collecting interests and demonstrate the depth and breadth of his passion for art and culture.

LIN FENGMIAN (1900-1991)
Farm Girls
Scroll, mounted and framed, ink and colour on paper
70 x 85 cm. (27 遜 x 33 遜 in.)
Signed, with one seal of the artist

Often seen subject-matters in Lin Fengmians oeuvre encompass flowers, still-life, autumnal forests, lotus ponds, reeds, egrets, elegant ladies and opera figures each with its own characteristics. Farm Girls perhaps was executed in Spring 1958 under particular circumstances, when Lin went to the countryside with artists Wu Dayu, Guan Liang, Lai Shaoqi and Chen Yanqiao to live with the farmers and paint their life. A product of its time, Farm Girls is a rarely seen example depicting a unique subject-matter.
The strong and vivid colours in Farm Girls have moved away from his earlier work inspired by Henri Matisse, and yet it still carries a synthesising undertone. Here, the expressiveness of the ink and colour in a composition with multiple vanishing points is combined with sense of light in the oil painting and watercolour tradition, with the colours displaying a subtle range of lightness. The curved lines that delineate the faces of the farm girls imbue the square composition with a harmonious sense of balance and geometric beauty.
While works depicting agricultural life in China such as Farm Girls can be read as a particular response to the political contexts and demands of the time, it can also be argued that with their distinctive simplicity, they form an integral part of Lin Fengmians artistic career.

lots.consigner_information: LOT 1304 PROPERTY FROM THE AWARD WINNING ACTRESS - JOAN FONTAINE Beautiful, worldly, and with the sophisticated grace of a bygone era, Joan Fontaine (1917-2013) remains one of the most celebrated actresses of Hollywood's golden age. She ascended from the ranks of aspiring RKO starlets to an Academy Award-winning legend, a favourite of directors such as Alfred Hitchcock and the inspiration for countless young women seeking to make it big on the silver screen. Ms. Fontaine's elegance of spirit is embodied in her striking collection of fine art and memorabilia, the relics of a life as one of Hollywood's brightest stars. Decorated in an elegant and understated manner, her residence in Carmel, California was hung with the many works of fine art the actress acquired across her lifetime. The proceeds from the sale of this painting will be donated to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals - Monterey, California.

lots.consigner_information: THE FORRER COLLECTION OF CHINESE PAINTINGS Albert Kurt Forrer, migrated in 1946 to Shanghai as a Swiss merchant. Initially working for a Swiss import & export company, he learnt to speak, read and write Chinese. In 1949 he successfully established a barter trade system for international companies in Shanghai. In the mid 1950's he accepted the position as director of the Swiss Aluminium Rolling Mills in Shanghai. He and his wife, Marfried Zubler, who shared similar interests in contemporary Chinese art and Chinese antiques, married in 1950 and had two sons. The young couple combined their collections of artwork and expanded it extensively over the next decade. They mainly focused on contemporary Chinese paintings, antiques and stone rubbings. Together, their collection includes artists such as Pang Zhao, also known as Pang Zuoyu (1915-1969), Fu Shuda (1910-1973)and Lin Fengmian (1900-1991). They focusing a significant part of their collection around his works and style. They knew the artist personally and acquired the paintings directly from him. Beside many works by the artist from his early days to 1960 the collection contains many paintings of Lin's successful students like Ai Vee Li as well as stunning paintings by unknown artists, attributed to the School of Lin Fengmian. The present collection of Lin Fengmian paintings stem from his peak period (1950-1960) and form a very strong and interesting body of work that demonstrates the diversity of Lin's practice at that time.

lots.consigner_information: FROM A PRIVATE HONG KONG COLLECTION (LOTS 1309-1312) This Hong Kong collection comes from the former collection of Mr Ximu, a native of Lin Fengmians hometown of Meixian, Guangdong province. Lins paintings form the majority of the collection, including pieces dedicated to his compatriots from Guangdong such as Xu Dongbai, who was a native of Dongguan and studied oil paintings (Lot 1312). Interestingly, all the works in this collection were produced in the 1940s in Chongqing, including numerous pieces by the teaching faculty from the National Academies of Fine Arts and Nanjing Central University Fine Art Department who had followed the Nationalist governments retreat to Sichuan. The collection offers an intimate portrait of the close artistic exchanges between artists and government officials gathered in wartime Chongqing, recorded in verse, calligraphy and painting. Part of the collection was sold in Christies 2018 Spring and Autumn sales.

lots.title_secondary_txt: Heroines of the Yangs-Mu Guiying Taking Command
lots.consigner_information: Heroines of the Yangs-Mu Guiying's Taking Command and Seated Lady by Lin Fengmian belong to a Norwegian shipping company executive. In 1945 he was assigned to work at the Hong Kong branch and occasionally went to Shanghai in the 1950s to 1960s. Through a doctor friend from Hong Kong, he met Lin Fengmian and visited his studio in Shanghai, purchasing several works by the artist. The colour and composition of Lin Fengmian's paintings are heavily reminiscent of Western oil paintings, yet through careful study of subject matter and brushwork one can easily recognize the deep-seated Chinese touch which the artist inserts in all his works. Lin Fengmian's interest in Chinese Opera began in the early 1950s. The artist was captivated by the dynamic poses struck by Chinese Opera dancers, which reminded him of French Cubism. In Heroines of the Yangs-Mu Guiying's Taking Command, Lin depicts the steps and movements of the characters with invisible lines using geometric forms, their masks well-researched for its accurate reflection of specific operas delineated in vibrant colours. Lin Fengmian's inspiration for drawing ladies comes from Chinese ceramics and the famous ceramics of the Tang and Song dynasty. Song dynasty ceramics are well-known for their almost-translucent thinness and delicate curves, and Lin borrowed the same imagery to create fragile, elegant women similar to that of a precious 'white jade' ceramic piece that is inviting and irresistable. In Seated Lady, Lin cleverly presents these Chinese themes and contexts in a Western manner - with an understanding of both Eastern and European culture, Lin appealed to the tastes of European visitors in Shanghai and Hong Kong, who brought his pieces back to Europe with them and remained in their collections until now.

lots.consigner_information: THE FORRER COLLECTION OF CHINESE PAINTINGS Albert Kurt Forrer, migrated in 1946 to Shanghai as a Swiss merchant. Initially working for a Swiss import & export company, he learnt to speak, read and write Chinese. In 1949 he successfully established a barter trade system for international companies in Shanghai. In the mid 1950's he accepted the position as director of the Swiss Aluminium Rolling Mills in Shanghai. He and his wife, Marfried Zubler, who shared similar interests in contemporary Chinese art and Chinese antiques, married in 1950 and had two sons. The young couple combined their collections of artwork and expanded it extensively over the next decade. They mainly focused on contemporary Chinese paintings, antiques and stone rubbings. Together, their collection includes artists such as Pang Zhao, also known as Pang Zuoyu (1915-1969), Fu Shuda (1910-1973)and Lin Fengmian (1900-1991). They focusing a significant part of their collection around his works and style. They knew the artist personally and acquired the paintings directly from him. Beside many works by the artist from his early days to 1960 the collection contains many paintings of Lin's successful students like Ai Vee Li as well as stunning paintings by unknown artists, attributed to the School of Lin Fengmian. The present collection of Lin Fengmian paintings stem from his peak period (1950-1960) and form a very strong and interesting body of work that demonstrates the diversity of Lin's practice at that time.

lots.consigner_information: LOTS 2759-2788 IMPORTANT CHINESE PAINTINGS - FORMERLY THE PROPERTY OF THE DR. K. S. LO COLLECTION Dr. K. S. Lo was born on 2 February 1910 in Guangdong, China. At age 10 he went to Malaysia with his mother and at age 20 he went to Hong Kong. In 1935 he graduated from the University of Hong Kong with a BA degree in commerce and business. After graduation he joined the company where his father worked and was soon appointed Hong Kong manager of the firm's real estate branch. Dr. K.S. Lo began his Vitasoy business in the winter of 1937, when he was 27 years old in Shanghai, after attending a talk on "Soya Bean: The Cow of China". His Vitasoy business grew to become one of the most recognized brands in Hong Kong and in many other global regions. Dr K.S. Lo had a great passion for Chinese art and culture, and he donated 605 yixing teapots and other tea ware pieces in 1995, enabling the creation of the K.S. Lo gallery at the Museum of Tea Ware, at Flagstaff House inside the Hong Kong Park (fig.1). Furthermore, Dr. Lo also donated many important ceramics from well-known major kilns from as early as the Western Zhou period to the 20th century. These paintings represent but a small part of his collecting interests and demonstrate the depth and breadth of his passion for art and culture.

lots.consigner_information: FROM A PRIVATE HONG KONG COLLECTION (LOTS 1340-1343) This Hong Kong collection comes from the former collection of Mr Ximu, a native of Lin Fengmians hometown of Meixian, Guangdong province. Lins paintings form the bulk of the collection, including pieces dedicated to his compatriots from Meixian such as Guo Guanjie, who was a native a Meixian and studied in France (Lot 1343). Interestingly, all the works in this collection were produced in 1940s Chongqing, including numerous pieces by faculty from the National Academies of Fine Arts and Nanjing Central University Fine Art Department who had followed the Nationalist governments retreat to Sichuan. Lin Fengmian, Pan Tianshou, Li Keran, Ding Yanyong, Xu Beihong and Zhao Shaoang are all represented in the collection, alongside key members of the Republican Government, such as Zou Lu and Liang Hancao. The collection offers an intimate portrait of the close artistic exchange between artists and government officials gathered in wartime Chongqing, recorded in verse, calligraphy and painting. Part of the collection was sold in Christies 2018 Spring sale.

lots.consigner_information: LOTS 3028-3029 FROM A NORWEGIAN PRIVATE COLLECTION In 1956, Lin Fengmian's wife, Alice Vatiaur, left China together with their daughter and son-in-law to settle in the West. These paintings come from the parents of the current owner, who bought them from Lin's wife in Hong Kong while she was on her way to Brazil. Two contrasting elements are at play in Goose Flying over the Willow Pond; the stillness of the hedges and the movement of the goose, revealed the perfect balance between quietness and liveliness of nature. Basking in the subtle luminosity, Lady Holding a Fan, is an excellent example of the artist at his best.

lots.consigner_information: THE FORRER COLLECTION OF CHINESE PAINTINGS Albert Kurt Forrer, migrated in 1946 to Shanghai as a Swiss merchant. Initially working for a Swiss import & export company, he learnt to speak, read and write Chinese. In 1949 he successfully established a barter trade system for international companies in Shanghai. In the mid 1950's he accepted the position as director of the Swiss Aluminium Rolling Mills in Shanghai. He and his wife, Marfried Zubler, who shared similar interests in contemporary Chinese art and Chinese antiques, married in 1950 and had two sons. The young couple combined their collections of artwork and expanded it extensively over the next decade. They mainly focused on contemporary Chinese paintings, antiques and stone rubbings. Together, their collection includes artists such as Pang Zhao, also known as Pang Zuoyu (1915-1969), Fu Shuda (1910-1973)and Lin Fengmian (1900-1991). They focusing a significant part of their collection around his works and style. They knew the artist personally and acquired the paintings directly from him. Beside many works by the artist from his early days to 1960 the collection contains many paintings of Lin's successful students like Ai Vee Li as well as stunning paintings by unknown artists, attributed to the School of Lin Fengmian. The present collection of Lin Fengmian paintings stem from his peak period (1950-1960) and form a very strong and interesting body of work that demonstrates the diversity of Lin's practice at that time.

lots.consigner_information: Heroines of the Yangs-Mu Guiying's Taking Command and Seated Lady by Lin Fengmian belong to a Norwegian shipping company executive. In 1945 he was assigned to work at the Hong Kong branch and occasionally went to Shanghai in the 1950s to 1960s. Through a doctor friend from Hong Kong, he met Lin Fengmian and visited his studio in Shanghai, purchasing several works by the artist. The colour and composition of Lin Fengmian's paintings are heavily reminiscent of Western oil paintings, yet through careful study of subject matter and brushwork one can easily recognize the deep-seated Chinese touch which the artist inserts in all his works. Lin Fengmian's interest in Chinese Opera began in the early 1950s. The artist was captivated by the dynamic poses struck by Chinese Opera dancers, which reminded him of French Cubism. In Heroines of the Yangs-Mu Guiying's Taking Command, Lin depicts the steps and movements of the characters with invisible lines using geometric forms, their masks well-researched for its accurate reflection of specific operas delineated in vibrant colours. Lin Fengmian's inspiration for drawing ladies comes from Chinese ceramics and the famous ceramics of the Tang and Song dynasty. Song dynasty ceramics are well-known for their almost-translucent thinness and delicate curves, and Lin borrowed the same imagery to create fragile, elegant women similar to that of a precious 'white jade' ceramic piece that is inviting and irresistable. In Seated Lady, Lin cleverly presents these Chinese themes and contexts in a Western manner - with an understanding of both Eastern and European culture, Lin appealed to the tastes of European visitors in Shanghai and Hong Kong, who brought his pieces back to Europe with them and remained in their collections until now.

lots.consigner_information: Lots 1072-1073 FROM THE COLLECTION OF AN ENGLISH GENTLEMAN These two paintings were owned by Frederick Duncan Foster (1919-2012). He left England in 1948 to work at Patons and Baldwins, a British woollen yarn factory in Shanghai, first as a company secretary and later as the general manager. He loved his new life in China where he made many good friends and enjoyed collecting art as well as fine furniture. In 1954, he decided to return to his homeland and he was allowed to take all his belongings, including these two paintings, back to England.These paintings were hung in his house for continued enjoyment for over 50 years until his death.

lots.consigner_information: LOTS 1610 - 1621 PROPERTY FROM THE COLLECTION OF THE LATE PROFESSOR ARTHUR LIM Professor Arthur Lim Siew Ming (1934 - 2014) was born on 24 April 1934 in Hong Kong. His parents strongly encouraged and supported the development of his many talents, and he completed his early education in Singapore. In 1956, Prof. Lim graduated from University of Malaya with the degree of MBBS. Later, he proceeded to specialize in ophthalmology and became the first Singaporean to obtain the Fellowship of the Royal College of Surgeons of London in 1962. In 1965, Prof Lim started a private practice named Eye Clinic Singapura, the platform from which he helped to establish the Singapore National Eye Centre (SNEC), eventually evolving itself into one of the largest private eye care group practices in Southeast Asia. Prof. Lim is acknowledged by his peers as the father of this specialist field of medicine in Southeast Asia, and a mentor and icon to eye surgeons all over the world. Since 1986, Prof. Lim led a major movement in China to control mass cataract blindness, as he felt that China was in its developing stage and more aid should be provided to help patients recovered from the vision illness. In recognition of his contributions, Prof. Lim was given the Friendship Award in 1996 by the China government, the highest award that can be bestowed on a foreign national. Singapore Ministry of Health even commented that his great contribution to China from 1986 to 1996 had indeed boosted the positive image of Singapore which ultimately enhanced the close cooperation of Singapore and China. He received the Business China Excellence Award in 2012. Furthermore, Prof. Lim was a passionate collector of art, supporting emerging artists from the region over his decades-long collecting, as well as amassing an impressive collection of over 800 pieces ranging from old masters in the Chinese and South-East Asian category to Western masters. Prof. Lim's eye for beauty and passion for the arts started since young - as an avid art collector, Prof Lim was listed in "ARTnews" as among the 200 great art collectors in the world. Two works from the same collection will be on offer in our Chinese Contemporary Ink auction on 1 June 2015 (Lots 916, 917).

lots.title_secondary_txt: Goose Flying over the Willow Pond
lots.consigner_information: LOTS 3028-3029 FROM A NORWEGIAN PRIVATE COLLECTION In 1956, Lin Fengmian's wife, Alice Vatiaur, left China together with their daughter and son-in-law to settle in the West. These paintings come from the parents of the current owner, who bought them from Lin's wife in Hong Kong while she was on her way to Brazil. Two contrasting elements are at play in Goose Flying over the Willow Pond; the stillness of the hedges and the movement of the goose, revealed the perfect balance between quietness and liveliness of nature. Basking in the subtle luminosity, Lady Holding a Fan, is an excellent example of the artist at his best.

lots.consigner_information: Lot 1074 from a private american collector Boat Trackers was originally owned by Katharine Giltinan Bowen (1887-1973), who lived in Beijing from 1935-1940 and 1946-1949. As indicated by a handwritten note on the back of the painting, Mrs. Bowen, who was an enthusiast of music and art, likely acquired this painting in 1940. Mrs. Bowen lived in Beijing with her husband, Trevor Pryse Bowen (1886-1960), a businessman, accountant and author from Wales. Long employed by the Rockefeller Foundation, Mr. Bowen worked in China as Comptroller of the Peking Union Medical College. He was awarded the Jingxing Medal and Certificate in 1948 by Chiang Kaishek and Wang Shijie. Lin Fengmian's engaging river scene has remained with and has been enjoyed by the Bowen family until the present.

lots.consigner_information: LOTS 2275-2284 PROPERTY FROM THE DE YI XUAN COLLECTION The owner of De Yi Xuan has travelled extensively for his career in West Africa and North America. His first interest in Chinese paintings was sparked by an exhibition in Africa in 1979, where Chinese artists such as Wu Guanzhong were showcased on the continent for the first time. He later relocated to North America, and with his passion he became a student of artist He Baili, at the same time began to form his own collection of paintings. Through collecting he became friends with renowned collector Wang Jiqian, where he learned extensively from Wang's precious collection. He also got to know artists such as Cheng Shifa, Zhu Qizhan and Tang Yun, all of whom have guided him throughout his journey of collecting and acquiring knowledge in Chinese paintings.

lots.consigner_information: THE FORRER COLLECTION OF CHINESE PAINTINGS Albert Kurt Forrer, migrated in 1946 to Shanghai as a Swiss merchant. Initially working for a Swiss import & export company, he learnt to speak, read and write Chinese. In 1949 he successfully established a barter trade system for international companies in Shanghai. In the mid 1950's he accepted the position as director of the Swiss Aluminium Rolling Mills in Shanghai. He and his wife, Marfried Zubler, who shared similar interests in contemporary Chinese art and Chinese antiques, married in 1950 and had two sons. The young couple combined their collections of artwork and expanded it extensively over the next decade. They mainly focused on contemporary Chinese paintings, antiques and stone rubbings. Together, their collection includes artists such as Pang Zhao, also known as Pang Zuoyu (1915-1969), Fu Shuda (1910-1973)and Lin Fengmian (1900-1991). They focusing a significant part of their collection around his works and style. They knew the artist personally and acquired the paintings directly from him. Beside many works by the artist from his early days to 1960 the collection contains many paintings of Lin's successful students like Ai Vee Li as well as stunning paintings by unknown artists, attributed to the School of Lin Fengmian. The present collection of Lin Fengmian paintings stem from his peak period (1950-1960) and form a very strong and interesting body of work that demonstrates the diversity of Lin's practice at that time.

lots.title_primary_txt: SHI LU (1919-1982) / WU ZUOREN (1908-1997) / LIN FENGMIAN (1900-1991) / GUAN SHANYUE (1912-2000) / WU GUANZHONG (1919-2010) and others
lots.description_txt:
SHI LU (1919-1982) / WU ZUOREN (1908-1997) / LIN FENGMIAN (1900-1991) / GUAN SHANYUE (1912-2000) / WU GUANZHONG (1919-2010) and others
Celebration Album
Album of eight leaves, ink and colour on paper
Inscribed and signed, with a total of eleven seals
Dedicated to Ziyun
Attached with letters to Ziyun by Lin Fengmian, Wu Guanzhong, Guan Shanyue & He Haixia

PROVENANCE :
Lot 115, 30 September 1991, Fine 19th and 20th Century Chinese Paintings, Christies Hong Kong.
Lot 2553, 30 November 2010, Fine Chinese Modern Paintings, Christies Hong Kong.

NOTE :
The recipient of this painting is the renowned sculptor and art historian Wang Ziyun (1897-1990). Born in Xuzhou, Jiangsu, he studied in France in 1931, and returned to China to teach at the Hangzhou National Art College. One of his greatest achievements was setting up the Northwest Art and Cultural Relics Exploration Mission to the Northwest in the 1940s. Since Wu Guanzhong was a student at the Hangzhou National Art College, he addressed Wang as teacher in the letter.
Various sizes, each leaf approximately measures 32 x 34 cm. (12 5/8 x 13 3/8 in.)

lots.consigner_information: LOTS 2986-2993 A PRIVATE HONG KONG COLLECTION This collection of paintings comes from a range of artists,many from the Lingnan school.Though small in size, they nonetheless showcase each individual artists style and skill. Qi Baishis Pomegranate can be appreciated by audiences with refined and popular tastes alike, demonstrating the broadness of his artistic range.The balance between robustness and beauty in Wu Hufans Bamboo embodies characteristics of classical scholarly paintings.Although there are differences in the styles of Pu Ru and Lin Fengmians female figures, they are equally elegant and beautiful. From flowers, animals to landscape, this collection showcases the versatility and artistry of the Lingnan school artists. This compilation of delectable treasures is a testament to the collectors passion for collecting.

lots.consigner_information: The Collection of Mr. Lin Shengyang An ancestral native of Chenghai, Guangdong, Lin Shengyang was a famous modern abstract artist. Born in Bangkok in 1917, Lin lived there for 20 years. He studied advertising design at an Art School in Bangkok, which confirmed his desire to dedicate his life to art. At the height of the Sino-Japanese War in 1939, Lin's patriotism led him to return to Kunming and study at the Hangzhou National Art Institute, where he graduated in 1944 and then stayed on in China to teach. Lin studied at the Institut d'Etudes Superieures des Arts in Paris for two years beginning in 1950. Later he attended the Bienal International de Sao Paulo in 1959 and subsequently settled in Brazil permanently, selling his art and teaching to make a living. Lin later taught at the Art Institute of Sao Paulo, where he received many accolades for his dedication as a teacher and a promoter of cross-cultural awareness. Lin's passionate interest in the arts led him to meet artists Zhang Daqian, Huang Junbi, Zhao Shao'ang and Guan Liang in China, Taiwan, Brazil and Hong Kong, and they dedicated paintings to him as a sign of their friendship.

Note:
The seal Xie Hang Lou Cang on the mounting was the collector's seal of renowned artist Fang Junbi (1898-1986). Fang was descended from a prominent family in Minhou, Fujian. As the first Chinese female student to be admitted to the prestigious ?c?le Nationale Sup?rieure des Beaux-Arts, Fang was often honoured as an outstanding artist from the East. She returned to China in 1933 and soon began her career in classical Chinese paintings. Fang sought to develop Chinese landscape paintings through reinterpreting reality and by incorporating Western-style perspective in her paintings.
Fang and her husband Zeng Zhongming are both collectors of seals, paintings, and calligraphy. Part of their collection was exhibited in Geneva in 2002 and featured works of art from Ming and Qing dynasties, as well as from the modern times.
